awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Linking population dynamics and behavior to understand how wildfire modifies the prevalence of zoonotic disease
awd_abstract_narration:
An estimated 60% of pathogens that affect humans, including the novel coronarvirus, also infect wild animals. This project examines Sin Nombre virus (SNV), a causative agent of hantavirus pulmonary syndrome in humans, in wild mouse populations. In particular, this work evaluates how wildfires, which are increasing in frequency and severity, affect disease dynamics. Knowledge of wildfire effects on disease in animal populations is incomplete because pre-fire data rarely exist to make informed post-fire comparisons, and because wildfires can simultaneously affect animal behavior, abundance, and movement. This project will help identify mechanisms whereby wildfire modifies disease in animals, thereby providing benefits to society by improving the ability to predict how future wildfires will affect disease in wildlife and humans. The project will also provide ways to mitigate human disease risk by identifying which intervention strategies are likely to be most successful for reducing post-fire disease in wildlife populations. Through outreach the project will educate the public about how wildfire affects infectious disease. In addition, the project will provide significant opportunities for training graduate students underrepresented in STEM fields. 

This project evaluates how wildfire affects the prevalence of SNV via the effects of wildfire on deer mouse (Peromyscus maniculatus) demography and behavior. Intensive immediate post-fire demographic, behavioral, and environmental data will be combined with existing long-term, pre-fire data. The project occurs on Santa Cruz Island, CA and capitalizes on a recent wildfire in June 2020. The objective of the project is to evaluate three hypotheses that link disturbance and the prevalence of zoonotic disease. 1) Sex-based differences in dispersal yield changes in prevalence by altering the composition of post-fire populations. 2) Changes in vegetative structure in post-fire habitats drive local changes in animal abundance that modify contact rates and disease prevalence. 3) Homogeneous resources and risk in post-fire habitats serve to synchronize the timing of animal activity, increasing contact rates and prevalence.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Many diseases that have significant effects on human health (e.g., Lyme disease, COVID-19) are diseases that exist in animal populations and can also be transmitted to humans.  Sin Nombre virus is found in wild deer mice and can have serious human health consequences, including very high rates of mortality in infected humans (e.g., approximately 40% of cases).  As a result, understanding the factors that affect animal-borne diseases, such as Sin Nombre virus, is essential for being able to predict situations where human disease risk is greatest.  However, our ability to predict disease risk is limited because the relationships between ecological factors and disease can be complex and are poorly understood.  This knowledge gap might be particularly important in the context of disturbances, such as wildfire, that are common and projected to become more so.  For example, wildfires might affect Sin Nombre virus in rodent populations if post-fire habitats are more likely to be colonized by infected mice, if post-fire habitats are areas where mice engage in behaviors that foster disease transmission (e.g., aggressive interactions can change disease transmission), or both.

 

Despite the increasing frequency and severity of wildfires worldwide, and the potential importance of wildfire in driving disease in wildlife, our ability to understand how wildfires affect animal-borne disease is limited because it is not possible to predict where wildfires will happen, and thus it is difficult to study disease dynamics before and immediately after a fire has happened.  This research project coupled existing data and immediate post-fire sampling to evaluate the effect of wildfire on the prevalence of Sin Nombre Virus (SNV) in wild mice.  Following a wildfire that occurred on Santa Cruz Island, we conducted field sampling of mice in 22 paired burned and unburned locations, collecting extensive demographic data, behavioral data, and sampling individuals for SNV.  Our resulting dataset consisted of 6 sampling sessions that spanned the period from fall of 2020 until fall of 2022; 230 individual mice were sampled during this effort.  Although our analyses are ongoing, we find that mice in post-fire habitats exhibited significantly higher rates of SNV prevalence.  In particular, our results suggest that changes in demography following wildfire may be responsible for changes in the prevalence of zoonotic disease: reproductive males, which are also the most aggressive individuals and most likely to transmit and carry disease, were found more often in post-burn habitats.  Changes in disease prevalence did not seem linked to changes in behavior in post-burn habitats; instead they seemed driven by differences in the kinds of individuals (in particular, reproductive males) that were more common in those habitats.  For scientists and public health staff seeking to minimize human exposure to disease, the findings from this project indicate that areas where Sin Nombre virus are endemic are areas where predictable increases in the prevalence of human disease risk will occur following wildfire, and these areas should be avoided during the seasons when aggressive interactions among mice are greatest.  Our findings also inform the larger field of zoonotic disease ecology:  by demonstrating that wildfire can be profitably linked to changes in demography that predict changes in disease risk.  This work should be useful for understanding other diseases where mice are key hosts (e.g., many tick-borne diseases, such as Borrelia burgdorferi, the causative agent of Lyme disease), as well as for helping reveal how animal population dynamics and behavior can be used to predict how increasing global change (e.g., wildfires) will affect human health.  In addition to illustrating the overarching role of precipitation in affecting large-scale and long-term disease prevalence, the results of the project help directly inform the risk of human virus exposure on the California Channel Islands, an area that receives over 250,000 visitors a year.  In the course of conducting this research, we were also able to explore whether mice on islands with high disease prevalence have particular genes, revealing several genes that may be important for understanding disease risk in mice and potentially humans.   

 

This project has also provided training opportunities for two graduate students, one of whom is a first-generation female college student.  In addition, case studies from this work are used in Introductory Biology and Behavioral Ecology lectures at UW-Madison, serving to inform and enrich the learning of approximately 1,100 undergraduates during each year of the project.
